What unfortunate incident killed Alex Lowe and photographer friend Dave Bridges?

An avalanche.

	The two, and five other members of the expeditional team, were caught in the path of the avalanche with disastrous consequences.

questions.text: The expedition included Conrad Anker. What is Anker famous for?
questions.correct: Finding George Mallory's body on Mount Everest
options: The most climbs in the Andes
questions.explanation:
Finding George Mallory's body on Mount Everest.

	Just four months before the avalanche that killed Lowe, Anker found the body of George Mallory, an Everest climber who had been missing for seventy five years.

questions.text: On what mountain was Alex Lowe, when the avalanche took his life?
questions.explanation:
Shishapangma, Tibet.

	Shishapangma, is a peak of over 26,000 feet on the Chondgui Valley in southern Tibet.

questions.text: One of Alex Lowe's greatest achievements was the climb of the Great Tango Tower. Where is the 'tower'?
questions.explanation:
Pakistan.

	Sometimes referred to as 'the largest big wall on earth', the Great Tango Tower is a 20,500 foot peak in Pakistan.

questions.text: Alex Lowe reached the summit of Mount Everest twice in his lifetime.
questions.explanation:
True.

	In 1993 from the South and 1994 from the Kangshung Face.

questions.text: Which prestigious award did Alex Lowe receive in 1995?
questions.explanation:
The Underhill Award.

	He was honored by the American Alpine Club for outstanding achievement in Alpine climbing.

questions.text: Where did Alex Lowe stage a daring rescue of two stranded Spanish climbers?
questions.explanation:
Mount McKinley, Alaska.

	The two Spanish climbers were stranded on El Capitan, Mount McKinley, Alex scaled 400 feet up a steep icy incline carrying one of the climbers on his back, to a waiting rescue helicopter.

questions.text: Which visionary mountaineer, who died in 1992 was one of Alex Lowe's inspirations?
questions.explanation:
Mugs Stump.

	Alex Lowe had many nicknames, one of the most bizarre was 'the lung with legs', given to him by a rival climber after his solo ascent of Aconcagua while carrying heavy loads. Perhaps the most flattering thing said of him, was that if you brought him along on a first climb you would be cheating. This quiz was compiled with excerpts from Outside Online Magazine, and is my personal tribute to an outstanding athlete.
